published_attributes.title: About the course
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Target Audience

If you're not a developer, QA specialist or a DevOps person, chances are that the following terms might be confusing to you: frontend, backend, fullstack, React, Swift, Kotlin, Ruby, Java, JSON, Git, staging, to name just a few.

If so, the good news is that after completing this it won't be that vague anymore. What is more, this course is designed specifically for non-technical people, so it will be explained in a human-friendly way: what tech people do, how they do it, and why they do it.

The structure of the course

This course consists of 14 mini lessons - short videos explaining the basics of software development. Under each video you can find a transcript with underlined key concepts, often accompanied with additional resources. After each lesson there is one or two quiz questions. The score isn't counted, the questions are there to help you consolidate the knowledge.

The video lessons were created by ﾅ「kasz Szmelc - former Netguru Developer.

published_attributes.title: Introduction
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Transcript

Hello. My name is ﾅ「kasz and I'm a Ruby on Rails developer, here at Netguru. If you are here, it is very likely that you are not a developer, QA specialist, or Dev-Ops guy. It is also very likely that sometimes you might find the IT world a little bit daunting and sometimes you might not know what fancy names like PostgreSQL, Django, MongoDB, or GraphGL mean. If that's the case those videos are for you. Welcome to the series of videos where we explore the mysterious lives of developers, QA specialists, and Dev-Ops guys.

As you might not surprisingly know, Netguru is an IT company, no matter if we are account managers, developers, designers or recruitment specialists. We are all in the same boat. At Netguru, nothing can be accomplished by one single person. That's why it is very important to understand each other. However, it is very common that we do not know what exactly our colleagues do. This is especially visible when it comes to our tech stuff, so I would like to give you an introduction to what our tech stuff does, what tools they use, and how they use it. My goal with this course is to seal the gap between tech people and non-tech people at Netguru. If you work with developers, QA specialists or Dev-Ops guys on daily basis. And you don't feel too comfortable communicating with them. Or sometimes you just don't understand what they say, those videos are for you. I want to take you on a journey, where I will try to explain in a human-friendly way what tech people do, how they do it, and why they do it. We are also going to get a bit technical and talk about some programming languages, kit, and some programming frameworks.

Before we begin, let me tell you a bit about myself, as of July 2019, which is when I'm shooting this video, I will have been a Ruby and Rails developer here at Netguru for almost 2 years. I do not hold a computer science degree, and I start learning by myself. This is why, I dare to say, that I kind of understand what the struggle it might be to understand what's going on in the tech world. So without further ado let's start our course. I will try to start by explaining the differences between very basic things just to focus on more specific topics later on. So brace yourself and I'll see you in the next video!

published_attributes.title: The Difference between Frontend, Backend and Fullstack developer
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Transcript

[ Apple Commercial ] - Hello I'm MAC. - And I'm a PC. We've got a little network going here and uh it was very easy to set up. - We speak each other's language - We share our internet connection, all sorts of things we do together.

Watch the whole clip here:

Welcome to this video. What you've just seen, was a part of the classic MAC vs PC commercial. There's a reason why I showed you this. Long story short, MACs are shown as cool machines, whereas PCs are shown as the opposite of cool. In this video, we are going to talk about the differences between front-end developers back-end developers, and full-stack developers. Let me start with some stereotypes. In our case, front-end developers would be the cool kids because this is what people think they do.

Whereas backend developers would be the uncool kids because this is 90% of what they do.

This of course doesn't tell you much. It doesn't tell me much either. So let me start with some more verbose explanation of what back-end developers do with some examples.

Back-end developers

When talking about back-end developers a very general definition of their work would be handling server-side logic. This is not very self-explanatory so let me give you a couple of examples. Back-end developer's work has a lot to do with data in general. They directly interact with data in the database. Say, you want to change your location on Facebook. This is back-end developers' work to create a necessary endpoint to enable that. Here, I mentioned an important word endpoint what endpoint is you're going to find out later in that course.

They also deal a lot with authentication and authorization. The difference between authentication and authorization is as follows. Let's imagine a situation where you want to log into your Facebook account. Handling the data that you fill the form with is called authentication. After you log in and want to access certain groups or fan pages. What you are able to see and what you are not allowed to see is called authorization.

Last but not least back-end developers provide data for front-end developers. Most often in form of JSON files. What is a JSON file and how it works? You're going to find out later in an episode where I talk about cooperation between back-end developers and front-end developers.

Front-end developers

When it comes to front-end developers. If I were to point out their main tasks, they would be as follows:

  • They consume the data that is provided from the backend and present this data in a visually attractive way.
  • They also work closely with designers, creating application layouts and templates.
  • Another very important front-end task is making applications accessible for various users and various devices.

Fullstack developers

And then we have someone who's called a full stack developer. Full-stack developer is a combination of a back-end developer and a front-end developer. It's someone who feels proficient in both back-end and front-end. It's that simple.

So to recap this episode we now know what the back-end developer does what the front-end developer does and what the full-stack developer does.

In the next episode, we're going to talk about some backend languages. See ya 汨欺u003c/p>

draft_attributes.title: What does a backend developer do?

published_attributes.title: Backend Languages
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Transcript

Okay, welcome to this episode. Now that we know what back-end developers do, let's sail deeper and talk about what languages they speak. In this episode, I'm going to present you with various languages that are used for back-end development. We're mostly going to focus on the ones that we use at Netguru and under application. however, to show you that there are many more I'm also going to mention some languages that we don't use here at Netguru.

Backend Languages

Not surprisingly I'm going to start with Ruby. Ruby is very very important for Netguru because Netguru started with Ruby, and Ruby is a big part of Netguru's success. In fact, if you take a look at Netguru's Github profile it still says, Ruby on Rails and mobile development house.

> Actually we've changed it already, here is the newest description:

This definition is quite out of date because we do a lot more than Ruby on Rails today.

Small remark: don't confuse ruby with Ruby on Rails

You're going to find out what the difference is later on. So Ruby is a language mainly used for building a backend of web applications. It's very popular because it's simple and is said to be the programmer's best friend. This is because its syntax is very friendly and is read almost like the English language. Many people have been complaining that Ruby is dying and will no longer be popular. It's still a lie in spite of what people say but it has serious competition from elixir which is the language I'm going to cover next.

Elixir is a rising star of the backend however, It's not as widespread as Ruby. Many people predict that it will gain Ruby's popularity one day. It is also used for developing backend of web applications. The reason why it's predicted to replace Ruby is that it's much faster. Whether it's going to replace Ruby one day - time will tell.

Let's focus on Python now. Python is the next language that we use at Netguru. You may have heard of it. It's currently one of the most popular programming languages and it has a wide array of applications. Here at Netguru, we use python to write the backend of applications and for machine learning purposes. It is also widely used in science.

JavaScript, when you are in tech all you hear is "Javascript this and Javascript that". That's because it's very very ubiquitous. It may currently be the most popular programming language it has as many haters as fans but the truth - is it's everywhere. It can be used for both the backend and frontend. That means that the person who knows javascript can write both the backend and front-end of an application using one language. From the business point of view, this means that the client can hire one developer which means spending less money. Isn't that beautiful? Although it sounds nice in theory, reality can be very different. Which you're also going to see in this course.

Those were the backend languages that we embrace at Netguru. However, there are many many more but we're not going to focus on them. But just to make you aware that the choice of which programming language to learn may be very difficult. Let me name a few

  • Java
  • PHP
  • C#

Okay and that's it for this episode. We now know what languages are used by back-end developers but what about languages that are used by front-end developers? We're going to talk about this in the next episode. See ya 汨欺u003c/p>

published_attributes.title: Frontend Languages
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Transcript

Welcome, in this video. In this episode, we are going to talk about what languages are necessary for frontend developers and what is their purpose. I'm also going to do a little live coding session but have no fear, it's not going to be too complicated. I just want to show you how different languages work with each other, so let's start.

Frontend Langauges

There are three main languages that frontend developers have to know. It's HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

Here, I would like to point out one very important thing JavaScript is not java.

This is a very common misconception, and I would like you to avoid this newbie mistake.

HTML

Let's start with HTML. I'm pretty sure that you might know this name,ﾂ might have even used HTML yourself, or at least know what it's used for. If you google HTML to check what it stands for, you're going to see that its full name is hypertext markup language. Again, not very self-explanatory, isn't it? No worries. What I would like you to know is that HTML is used for creating templates. So let's jump into my text editor and see how it works.

Okay, so this is going to be a really short demonstration. What you see here is a pure html template. So I'm just going to create a container and then I'm just going to place a simple paragraph which says 窶彡lick me窶. This is what we've just created. There are two problems with it. One; it's ugly second when I click 窶彡lick me窶 nothing happens. So let's see what we can do about this and talk about CSS.

CSS

You might remember what I said about frontend developers in one of the last videos. Their task is to present content in a visually attractive way. And here comes CSS. It stands for cascading style sheets. It is a language used for styling and animating elements. So let me add a bit of style to my ugly element. Okay, so here we are in the editor again. So let me add a place where I'm going to define the styling. Then let me identify my element by (should be for?) example div (what?) and let's make it 200 pixels high; 200 pixels wide, and let's make it maybe red, so it stands out. Okay, so now when I refresh the site you're gonna see that the new style has been applied. Voila.

Still, when I click on my element, nothing happens, and that's where JavaScript comes in.

JavaScript

So let's talk about JavaScript then. Let me remind you one more time: JavaScript is not Java. I realize I may be annoying, but that's very important to remember. It's really difficult to say what JavaScript does. If I was lazy I would just say that JavaScript does everything but that wouldn't tell you much, so let me put it this way: in terms of front-end development, JavaScript handles users' interactions with the application. Let's imagine that you click or tap on something, and that causes another element to update. It's probably JavaScript.

In another situation; let's say you click on a link and a pop-up or a model window appears. Again, that's probably JavaScript.

So let me show you JavaScript in action.

Okay, so here we are in my editor again. I'm going to add some action to my element. So let me first add a script tag, then I'm going to identify my element, and then I'm going to assign an action to click my element. So let's move to the browser again and when I refresh the site and click the element. Something should happen. Let's see if it works. I click the element and I have a message.

See this what JavaScript can do. Okay, no more coding for now. Now we know what are the languages used by backend and frontend developers. Let's sum up this video. We learned that the main languages used by frontend developers are HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Html is used for templating CSS is used for styling and JavaScript is used for handling users' interactions with an application. That's it for now.

Thanks for watching and see you in the next video.

published_attributes.title: Software framework
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Transcript

Hello and welcome in this video. In previous episodes, we learned about different back-end and front-end languages. However, almost everything can be written in any language. So, did you think why divide programming languages into background languages and frontend languages? The answer is 窶徭oftware framework.窶 If you're in tech you hear about frameworks all the time but what is a software framework? The first thing one does when one does know something is using Google. So let's use Google to find out what the software framework is. Okay so, I'm in google, and let me just type 窶徭oftware framework窶 and see what I get. Let's go to Wikipedia and read the definition.

> https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_framework > And computer programming a software framework is an abstraction with software for an internet functionality can be selectively changed by additional user-written code thus providing application-specific software.

That's not a very friendly definition, is it? My definition of a software framework would be: 窶彌u003cstrong>a tool created in a certain programming language used to facilitate creating applications.窶 I hope you're going to agree that this is way easier to understand. However, let me explain to you in a bit more detail what a software framework is.

So as I said almost anything can be created using any programming language. However, the problem is that writing applications from scratch is very time-consuming and error-prone because no one is able to predict every possible case. So a software framework is a set of ready-made tools written and tested by a bunch of smart people who had time and energy to write a big piece of software from scratch. However in order for a framework to work well, one has to learn the logic and rules of the framework and that's the main difficulty. In the case of a front-end framework, it can be learning how to make certain components and applications communicate with each other. Whereas in backend framework, it can be learning how to communicate and interact with the database according to this framework rules. I hope that the definition of a software framework is much clearer to you now.

I would just like to answer the question which he asked at the beginning of this video why divide languages into backend and frontend languages? Well, the answer is simple. There are certain backend frameworks created in some languages and frontend frameworks that use other languages.

In the next episode, we are going to talk a bit more about different frameworks and their applications.

However, the problem is that writing applications from scratch is very time-consuming and error-prone because no one is able to predict every possible case. So a software framework is a set of ready-made tools written and tested by a bunch of smart people who had time and energy to write a big piece of software from scratch. However in order for a framework to work well, one has to learn the logic and rules of the framework and that's the main difficulty. In the case of a front-end framework, it can be learning how to make certain components and applications communicate with each other. Whereas in backend framework, it can be learning how to communicate and interact with the database according to this framework rules. I hope that the definition of a software framework is much clearer to you now.

I would just like to answer the question which he asked at the beginning of this video why divide languages into backend and frontend languages? Well, the answer is simple. There are certain backend frameworks created in some languages and frontend frameworks that use other languages.
In the next episode, we are going to talk a bit more about different frameworks and their applications.

answers.body: No need to write application from scratch
Usually contains set of set of ready-made tools
Defines rules to keep code easy to be consistent

published_attributes.title: Backend frameworks
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Transcript

Welcome in this video. Now that we know what the framework is, let's talk about frameworks that you may hear about at Netguru. We are going to start by talking about backend frameworks.

Backend Frameworks

So first and foremost let me start with the framework that Netguru started with and which it owes a great deal of success. This is of course Ruby on Rails. Ruby on Rails is the main framework written in the Ruby language. There are other Ruby frameworks like sinatra and hanami, but when someone says - I'm a ruby developer - you can be almost sure that this means I'm a ruby on rails developer.

Ruby on Rails

So what is Ruby on Rails and what it's used for? Long story short it's used for writing the backend part of applications. Without going into technical details, it's known for convention over configuration principle, which means that it's a very opinionated framework that sometimes forces developers to solve problems taking the Rails way approach. Thanks to that Ruby on Rails codebase is predictable which is a good thing because it speeds up development a lot. When talking about the development speed with Ruby on Rails many things come out of the box which means it's a perfect solution for creating MVPs. Many people claim that Ruby on Rails is dying because it's not scalable and is slow. Those can, in fact, be the negative sides of Ruby, but truth be said, for 99% of projects what Ruby on Rails offers is completely sufficient, it's a well-established framework and is actively maintained which means it's not going anywhere anytime soon.

django

django is another backend framework that we use at Netguru. django is written in Python. However, things are not as simple as with Ruby on Rails. When someone says I'm a Python developer, it can mean many different things, because Python has more applications than Ruby. Basically, django would be the same thing as Ruby on Rails in terms of its application. It's also used for building the backend part of web applications. The biggest difference though would be a different programming language used. There might also be other minor technical differences, which may cause that some developers like or dislike this framework. Since I'm neither a Python developer nor django developer, I'm not eligible to talk about them. Bottom line however is that django is a Python based tool for building backend of web applications.

Node.js

At Netguru, you might also stumble upon someone who's called and Node.js developer. With Node.js things are slightly different. You might not know that but JavaScript is a client-side language, which means that it runs in the browser. However, Node.js changes that. Node.js is an environment which allows to run JavaScript code outside browsers. Like you would normally do with other programming languages, like Ruby or Python. This creates a whole lot of new opportunities because thanks to Node.js JavaScript can be used to write backend of applications as well and the code for both frontend and backend is going to look the same in terms of syntax. Consequently, that means that to build an entire application knowing JavaScript would be enough and that's a big deal in the tech world today.

And that would be it for backend frameworks there's of course a lot more but what I would like you to remember is that you can basically do the same stuff with all of them. The only difference would be different programming languages and the patterns that are imposed by the framework itself that developers need to follow.

In the next video we are going to talk about frontend frameworks. Thanks for watching see ya 汨欺u003c/p>

published_attributes.title: Frontend frameworks
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Transcript

Welcome in this video. In this episode we are going to talk about frameworks used by frontend developers. Let's dive into it.

Before we begin talking about the most popular frameworks as of 2019 let me stress one thing. Front-end world is much more different than the backend. Backend world has been based on a couple of well-established frameworks and hardly ever does it happen that a new framework appears and changes existing situation 180 degrees. In the front end world everything is much more dynamic and temporary. Five years ago currently the most popular framework didn't even exist. That creates a risk of this movie quickly becoming out of date. Nevertheless, let me present your current situation as of 2019.

At Netguru, we basically rely on three front-end frameworks. React, Vue and Angular. Comparing these frameworks would mean that we would have to get a little bit nerdy. Instead, I just want to explain to you some general rules of front frameworks and give you a short introduction to each of them.

Basically, this is how front frameworks work. There's some general app layout that consists of many components. A framework sets some guidelines as to how to write those components. The underlying principle is the same in every framework. Components consist of HTML CSS and JavaScript. In most cases, data in component A is dependent on data in component B, so there needs to be some communication between them and that's basically what the frontend framework does. It sets some guidelines for writing components and transferring data from one component to another. So if all front-end frameworks use JavaScript and the principle is similar everywhere why are there so many of them? React, Angular and Vue are just the ones that we use at Netguru, but trust me there's many more.

To answer this question we need to look at the bigger picture. As you know the internet has some big players. They want to control the modern tech world in any way possible.

There are the same big players behind some frontend frameworks React is a project by Facebook, whereas Angular is Google's kid. Companies like Google and Facebook have the capacity to promote their products. Knowing that there's a big player behind the framework gives developers some confidence that it's not going to be replaced quickly by another tool. Vue, however, is different. It's not supported by any big tech player. It's an open-source project created entirely by independent developers. Although it's been adapted by Netguru and classified as an area we want to explore. Its market sure is currently the lowest among those three mentioned frameworks. Don't get me wrong it doesn't mean that it's worse. It's just how things are.

Since we're not going to get too technical. Let's just stop here just to keep it simple. There are many front frameworks and they all use JavaScript. Technical differences between them are rather negligible. It's rather a question of personal preference and which framework has the biggest support on the market. Currently, it's React. I hope you enjoyed this video I'll see you in the next one.

published_attributes.title: Mobile Apps
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Transcript

Welcome in this episode. So far we've covered backend and frontend. And you might have started to ask yourself where are mobile apps at Netguru Do we do them? And the answer to this question is yes we do.

We are going to cover three types of mobile apps. And so it happens that we do all of them at Netguru. They're going to be

  • native apps
  • non-native apps
  • and progressive web apps

Native Applications

Let's start with native apps. As you probably know there are two main mobile operating systems. Android from Google and iOS from Apple. They are two completely different platforms each with its own ecosystem. They are written in different languages and that means that applications for both Android and iOS need to be written in different languages as well.

For iOS, it's Objective-C or Swift, and for Android, Java, or Kotlin. At Netguru we only do Kotlin for Android but both Objective-C and Swift for iOS. From a business point of view, two different ecosystems mean that a product owner needs to hire different developers for each operating system. consequently, that means more money to be spent. That's the problem that is solved by non-native applications.

Non-Native Applications

Non-Native apps are quite a new solution on the mobile apps market. They are apps that don't need to be written in language specific for each platform. How is that possible you may ask? Well, the answer is JavaScript. There are some JavaScript frameworks for developing mobile applications. The one we use at Netguru is called React Native. React Native like React is also developed by Facebook developers. It allows to write javascript code, which then gets bridged with native code resulting in applications that don't need any compromises. With small exceptions they work like native apps. The beauty of it is that code written in one language - JavaScript - is served by both platforms Android and iOS. If a product owner is ready to make small compromises in terms of app performance, this is our solution to write apps for both platforms.

Progressive Web Apps

And then we have PWA it stands for progressive web apps. PWA is another buzzword in today's tech world. Those are mobile apps that share exactly the same code as their desktop counterparts. Thanks to modern frontend frameworks it's possible to make modern website behave almost like a native app. They don't require installation and technically they run in a browser, but they've done well, they feel and behave almost like native applications.

If you want to see how it works check out wordguru game developed by Netguru.

http://netguru.com/wordguru

While they might not provide 100% as smooth and seamless experience as native or non-native apps if a product owner is ready to make some compromises PWA might be a good idea because it almost entirely eliminates the need to hire a mobile app developer.

And that's it for mobile development at Netguru. Now you know the difference between native applications, non-native applications, and progressive web applications.

I hope you enjoyed this video I'll see you next one.

Non-Native apps are quite a new solution on the mobile apps market. They are apps that don't need to be written in language specific for each platform. How is that possible you may ask? Well, the answer is JavaScript. There are some JavaScript frameworks for developing mobile applications. The one we use at Netguru is called React Native. React Native like React is also developed by Facebook developers. It allows to write javascript code, which then gets bridged with native code resulting in applications that don't need any compromises. With small exceptions they work like native apps. The beauty of it is that code written in one language - JavaScript - is served by both platforms Android and iOS. If a product owner is ready to make small compromises in terms of app performance, this is our solution to write apps for both platforms.

Progressive Web Apps

And then we have PWA it stands for progressive web apps. PWA is another buzzword in today's tech world. Those are mobile apps that share exactly the same code as their desktop counterparts. Thanks to modern frontend frameworks it's possible to make modern website behave almost like a native app. They don't require installation and technically they run in a browser, but they've done well, they feel and behave almost like native applications.

If you want to see how it works check out wordguru game developed by Netguru.

http://netguru.com/wordguru

While they might not provide 100% as smooth and seamless experience as native or non-native apps if a product owner is ready to make some compromises PWA might be a good idea because it almost entirely eliminates the need to hire a mobile app developer.

And that's it for mobile development at Netguru. Now you know the difference between native applications, non-native applications, and progressive web applications.

I hope you enjoyed this video I'll see you next one.

published_attributes.title: Backend and Frontend Cooperation
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Transcript

Welcome in this video so far we've talked a lot about backend and frontend and now it's time to sum it all up. In this episode, we are going to get our hands a little bit dirty. We've been through a lot of theory, so why don't we see how the flow between backend and frontend developer looks like.

We are going to be working under the app that tracks users expenses. This app uses Ruby on Rails on the backend and Vue in the frontend. So let's imagine a conversation between backend developer and frontend developer.

- Hey back-end developer I need to list users expenses. Could you write me an endpoint for that.

- Yep, hold my beer.

Ideally, frontend should be built on top of backend. Backend usually build something that's called an API (application programming interface). Don't worry about this complicated name. Imagine an API as a set of instructions. We like to call those instructions - endpoints. To read those instructions we need to call an endpoint. In this situation a frontend developer will call an endpoint to fetch the data provided by the backend and then present this data. Let's dive into it.

Let's start by looking up the data in the database. We are going to look for all users expenses. We would now have to create an endpoint that exposes this data. We are going to skip the process of creating the endpoint, but let me briefly explain what it is.

An endpoint is a certain address where you go and where you expect some data to be delivered. Just like you knock to your grandma's apartment and you expect your grandma. Or you knock to doctor's room and expect a doctor. That's pretty much it.

So let me call this endpoint and see what we get. What you see here is data in a JSON format. JSON is the most popular data exchange format and this is what we are delivering to frontend developers. Now a front-end developer needs to process this data and present it in a visually attractive way. I have already prepared the template for displaying expenses and all I need to do is just populate it with the data I get from the backend. So if we were to show how the data is processed, it would look as follows. It starts as raw data and database, then is exposed in a JSON format just to end up in a final template.

So this is what the cooperation between backend and front-end developers looks like in a nutshell. Of course, there's much more to it. I just wanted to show you a little backstage of the entire process. Other than this we also learned what an API and endpoints are. Just to remind you an API is a set of instructions and endpoints are just rules for those instructions.

And that's gonna be it for this video. I hope you enjoy this, and I'll see you in the next one.

published_attributes.title: Git and Github
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Transcript

Welcome in this episode. So far we've talked a lot about programming languages and frameworks. Those tools alone wouldn't get us too far. Developing an application is a team effort. The code needs to be managed and shared between developers. In this episode, we are going to talk about Git and Github let's dive into it.

Git

We are going to start with git let's take a look at the official definition.

> GIT is a distributed version control system for tracking changes in source code during software development.

Let's analyze this definition. When talking about Git, I think it's a good idea to use some comparisons. Before we do that, I have to introduce one crucial Git related word. The code repository is also known as just repository or repo. We can imagine a repo as a folder containing some files. The main difference though is the fact that Git repo stores very precise history of each file which means that if you are using files from any git repo you are able to see the exact history of a file. Who did what, why did he do it, and when did he do it. That's what version control stands for another very important part of Git definition is the word distributed. What exactly does it mean. It means that repositories can be accessed from any computer and they are going to look the same for every person accessing them. That means that every developer in a project can see an up-to-date version of applications code. See who, why make some changes and also move back to previous code versions if there's a need to.

Github

Let's talk about Github now. Github is just a web client that serves the Git system. Thanks to Github you can store and make your repositories accessible on the web. In other words, this is just a hub for the code which is accessible for developers involved in a project. Let's see what it looks like. This is Netguru's Github page. If we go to a sample repo we can see that this indeed looks like a folder with other folders and some files. This is a remote repository. Remote repository means that it's a repo stored on Github server. A local repo would be a repo that we have downloaded to our computer. We can go and explore each file. We can see who made what changes, why did he make them and when did he make them. The red part is the code that's been deleted and the green part is the code that's been added. This repo is accessible to everyone at Netguru and everybody can contribute. In order to do so, one just has to clone the repo. Cloning a repo is just downloading it on your computer. After the repo is on your computer, you can just push changes to the remote repo and the rest is history. That's how software is made.

And that's gonna be it for Git and Github. I hope that the concept of Git is clear to you now. Long story short Git is just a tool that helps developers track changes in the code and stay up to date with the latest version of the application.

I hope you enjoyed this video I'll see you in the next one.

published_attributes.title: Branches and Pull Requests
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Transcript

Welcome in this video. We are almost at the end of this series and it's time, to sum up what we know. In this and the following videos, I will be showing you what exactly developers' work looks like. I will be showing you every stage of developer's workflow. We will be talking about continuous integration, pull requests, staging, code review, and QA. Let's dive into it.

Now that we know what Git and Github are, we already talk about how the code flows. In this particular video, we will learn about pull requests and how we approach them at Netguru. By now you should already know where the repo is. Let's imagine I have to implement a small change in the application. The client wants to display a funny message after a link is clicked. Repo contains files with the code. One very important feature of Git repos is the ability to create branches. Just like the ones on the tree. This is also the metaphor that we are going to use. In our case the final version of an application, also called the master branch, would be the tree trunk. According to our Netguru flow, every new feature is written on a new branch. And that's exactly what I'm going to do first. I'm going to create a new branch in my local repo.

Feature branch is completely independent from the master branch. That means that if I'm writing code on my branch, it doesn't change the code on the master branch. I'm going to skip the part where I write the code, but let's assume I have already finished and I want to let my colleagues know that there's a new feature coming. In order to do this, I need to push the sprint to the remote repo on Github and create a pull request.

Pull Request

What is a pull request? Pull request is the way for developers to let each other know about suggested changes in the code. It is called a pull request because after the request is accepted the suggested changes are pulled by the master branch

just like that:

and the code on the master branch is updated with the code from the feature branch.

So let's go ahead and create a pull request. This is a sample pull request. in the description, we always need to write what changes have been made and what is their purpose.

Here we can compare what changes have been made compared to the master branch. Red is the code that has been deleted and green is the code that has been added.

Before we go further we need to talk about a few things that need to happen now. Developer needs to wait for a continuous integration build. Sometimes new staging environment is built and last but not least developer needs to wait for code review. We are going to talk about it all in the next episodes what I would like you to remember is that Git repos have branches and that developers create so-called pull requests where they suggest changes for the application.

I hope you enjoyed this video I'll see you in the next one.

Repo contains files with the code. One very important feature of Git repos is the ability to create branches. Just like the ones on the tree. This is also the metaphor that we are going to use. In our case the final version of an application, also called the master branch, would be the tree trunk. According to our Netguru flow, every new feature is written on a new branch. And that's exactly what I'm going to do first. I'm going to create a new branch in my local repo.

Feature branch is completely independent from the master branch. That means that if I'm writing code on my branch, it doesn't change the code on the master branch. I'm going to skip the part where I write the code, but let's assume I have already finished and I want to let my colleagues know that there's a new feature coming. In order to do this, I need to push the sprint to the remote repo on Github and create a pull request.

Pull Request

What is a pull request? Pull request is the way for developers to let each other know about suggested changes in the code. It is called a pull request because after the request is accepted the suggested changes are pulled by the master branch

just like that:

and the code on the master branch is updated with the code from the feature branch.

So let's go ahead and create a pull request. This is a sample pull request. in the description, we always need to write what changes have been made and what is their purpose.

Here we can compare what changes have been made compared to the master branch. Red is the code that has been deleted and green is the code that has been added.

Before we go further we need to talk about a few things that need to happen now. Developer needs to wait for a continuous integration build. Sometimes new staging environment is built and last but not least developer needs to wait for code review. We are going to talk about it all in the next episodes what I would like you to remember is that Git repos have branches and that developers create so-called pull requests where they suggest changes for the application.

I hope you enjoyed this video I'll see you in the next one.

published_attributes.title: Continuous Integration
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Transcript

Welcome in this video. In the last episode, I mentioned continuous integration. This name sounds scary, but in this video, you will find out what it is. So what is behind this fancy name - continuous integration - well there is no simple answer. Continuous integration is a software development practice in which a team is integrating small continuous changes into the codebase.

After each change that is pushed to a remote repo, a build is triggered. A build simply checks whether the application can be installed without any errors. It also runs all the tests which sometimes are called specs. This is all very important because the build and the tests need to run in a consistent environment. Developers use different computers settings operating systems and the application can behave differently between their machines. The main goal of continuous integration is ensuring that everything is performed in a consistent environment thus giving reliable outcome. At Netguru we use three continuous integration tools:

  • Circle CI
  • Travis CI
  • bitrise

Oftentimes builds can be a big impediment in the development process. Run times range from five minutes to an hour. This can seriously affect development velocity, but in order to provide predictable and reliable behavior of an application the build needs to end successfully, before the code is handed over for code review.

And that's basically all you need to know about continuous integration.

Bottom line it runs all the tests and ensures a consistent environment for building an application.

I hope you enjoyed this short episode I'll see you in the next one.

published_attributes.title: Staging Environments
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Transcript

Welcome in this episode. In previous videos we talked about pull requests and continuous integration. In this video we are going to talk about another thing that's important to know at this point. Staging environments.

First let's answer the question - what is a staging environment. Staging environment is a reflection of a production environment. Ideally staging would have similar data to the production. Similar amount of users messages and so on. This is because the amount of data can impact efficiency of some operations. What works locally doesn't have to work perfectly with larger amounts of data. The purpose of staging then is to test new features under production-like conditions to mitigate any risk when deploying to production. At Netguru we use two kinds of staging environments dynamic and static. Let's start with dynamic staging.

Dynamic Staging

Dynamic staging is created when a developer opens a pull request. Opening a pull request means that the developer is working on, is ready, thus it is ready to test. That means that for every pull request there is a new staging with a particular feature. After the pull request is merged and the corresponding branch is deleted the particular instance of staging is terminated.

Static Staging

The principle of static staging environment is completely different. There's only one staging environment that persists all the time. The instance of staging is rebuilt and refreshed only when the pull request is merged to the master branch. That means that this is the last stage before code is deployed to production.

Who uses staging?

Who is staging environment for. Is it for developer? Is It for quality assurance team? Is it for the client? The answer is it's for everyone except for end users. Developers can make sure that the features they've written work in real life conditions. Testers can also check the features and test them against edge cases. The client can see developers work and suggest final amendments before pushing to production.

And that's it for this video. What I would like you to remember is that staging is the last step before code is deployed to production. It's a reflection of a production environment but also is a playground where everyone can test new features without any consequences. You might also want to remember the difference between static staging and dynamic staging.

I hope you enjoyed this video I'll see you in the next one.

published_attributes.title: Code Review and QA
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Transcript

Welcome in this episode. We are going to continue our discussion about Netguru flow. We already know what the pull request is and what happens after it's opened. As staging is created and the continuous integration build is triggered. But we still haven't successfully merged our pull request. What needs to happen so we can do this. The answer is code review and QA.

As I mentioned previously when a developer creates a pull request he considers the code good and production ready. However there is always some discrepancy between expectations and reality. To many people's surprise developers are humans and humans make mistakes. That's why at Netguru we do code review. Code review is a process in which a fellow developer checks our code line by line and tries to suggest better solutions. This is beneficial for both sides, both reviewer and the author can learn a lot from code review and as a result the code is better. The person that's reviewing the code can leave some comments and reject the pull request.

In this case, the developer is asked for some amendments. And after the new and better code is written he needs to ask a colleague for another review. This can repeat as long as the code is not approved by the reviewer. As you might imagine the pursuit for better code can take some time.

After the code is approved the features are tested by a tester, or as we call it by a quality assurance specialist. They do not check the code itself, they check how the new feature or fix works in real life conditions on staging environment. Their role is very important. The code itself may look good at first glance, but it's only good when it performs well against QA and all edge cases. When the QA specialist rejects the feature entire process beginning from creating pull request needs to be repeated. If however the feature passes our quality assurance it's handed over to the client for final approval. And that's pretty much the entire process we have a lot of safety measures that ensure that the delivered code is of the highest quality. They may also make the entire process a bit long, however, rush is never advised for developers work. As the proverb says haste makes waste.

And at the end of the day it's all about client satisfaction.

And that's it for this video in this and previous episodes I wanted to give you some insight into developer's life. I want to show you the backstage of the entire process and explain to you why sometimes implementing even small changes can take a long time. And that's all because we always care about error-proof code.

I hope you enjoyed this video. I'll see you in the next one
